hero.copy: In 1903, on the corner of 17th and McGavock, the Addison Ave. Cumberland Presbyterian Church built a beautiful brick sanctuary. In 1968, Fred Foster, founder of Monument Records, purchased the church and converted it into a recording studio. In 2012, Zac Brown bought the same building and transformed it into a first-class facility that inspires creation and satisfies the appetites of artists and musicians from around the world.

readMore.title: Making Music History, Where Music History was Made.
copy: In 2012, Southern Ground was searching for a small studio space in Nashville to record and produce records for Southern Ground Artists. When we stumbled upon the site that would later become our home, we couldn't have fathomed the rich, musical history that had lived here for just over a century.

Located at the foot of Nashville's music row, the building that houses Southern Ground Nashville was originally built between 1897 and 1903, and served as the Addison Avenue Cumberland Presbyterian Church until the mid-1950s.

After a brief stint as a VFW Post, the facility was purchased by Fred Foster, owner of famed recording company Monument Records, and transformed into Monument Studio in 1968. Managed at the time by now-legendary engineers Mort Thomassen and Tommy Strong, many fabled country recordings were produced in this era, including Kris Kristofferson's first three albums.

In 1975, the studio was purchased by Chip Young, renamed Young'un Sound and permitted to continue its tradition of pumping out classic Nashville recordings well into the 1980s. Later, Al Jolson, Jr., son of the famous performer Al Jolson, purchased the studio and dubbed it with yet another new moniker: Masterlink Studio. It was during this era that the building transformed into a high-tech facility specializing in audio for video remixing, including mixes for TNN (Hee Haw, CMT, etc.)

In the 1990s and 2000s, the walls of Masterlink witnessed a number of celebrated recordings, including that of Neil Young's "Prairie Wind" album. But due to his ailing health, Jolson was forced to shut the studio down in 2010. It sat vacant for nearly two years, and, at one point, was in serious danger of becoming a Mexican restaurant.

When Southern Ground acquired the studio in 2012, we began by renovating the now 100-year-old building to restore much of its original character.  A Mix room was also added that includes an SSL 4000G+ console ATC 300's and a small overdub space.

We were also lucky enough to inherit some of the classic recording gear that Masterlink left behind, including a Neve V3, 48 tracks of 2" analog tape, Ampex ATR-102 master 2-track recorder and vintage Neumann U47/U48 microphones (perhaps better known as The Beatles microphone).

Thanks to our new location, incredible on-site talent and the impeccable taste in recording equipment of those who came before us, we now have the ability to efficiently produce albums from start to finish, using a hybrid of classic analog and modern digital technology, all under one roof.

details.description:
Studio A is our flagship studio, filled with the vibe and love synonymous with all things Southern Ground. Whether you’re looking to make a throwback retro album or a sleek modern one, we can help your imagination come to life in this one of a kind space.

We know your time at the studio is at a premium and we want to help you make the most it while you’re here. Studio A bookings include a house assistant to help maximize your studio time. Our knowledgeable assistants are fully trained in each room and ready to help your dreams become reality.

Our carefully curated collection of vintage and state-of-the-art equipment and instruments offer endless possibilities. The large tracking space offers high ceilings and the best live drum room in Nashville. With our 3 solo isolation booths and dedicated 2 guitar amp isolation booths, you can have as much isolation as you need or want. This room also includes 3 EMT 140 plates and 1 small echo chamber.

Studio A is much more than just a space to track and record music. Each booking includes one home-cooked meal per day from our studio kitchen, made from scratch by our own Studio Mama. These meals offer a special opportunity to have home-cooked food while discussing, reflecting, and planning your time in our studio. Southern Ground offers a full-service experience you won’t forget.
specs: API Legacy Plus 48ch with 500 Series Bucket
Atomic Instrument "Reactors" main speakers and Barefoot MicroMain 27 Nearfield speakers

details.description: Studio B is the perfect place to mix for a week or simply finalize your mixes for the day. Acoustically designed by Steve Durr and Associates, it is a fantastic sounding and very comfortable room with a healthy assortment of gear. Last minute overdubs are also easy with the overdub room downstairs.
specs: ATC 300s Mains and Yamaha NS-10M Nearfields

details.description: Studio C offers a very intimate feel perfect for writing, overdubs, post-production, and small tracking sessions. With 3 isolation booths, it is possible to track a band at once or setup for layering on a previous recording. It includes many instruments and amps as well as a private kitchenette.

The Southern Ground Nashville kitchen is a place where artists and crew come together to share in a communal meal. There’s something really special about breaking in the middle of a session and coming down to the kitchen after working hard and being teased with delicious smells throughout the day. A nutrient-rich meal sourced from local, organic farms keeps artists alert and creative instead of getting tired or “sludgy” on fast food. The aesthetic is warm and welcoming, too. Just being in this space feels like a good respite!
specs: Thorens Record Player and Marantz Stereo
Rebecca Wood, a freezer full of local goodness and cast iron!

details.description: Where the broken come back to life!

questions.question: Position at Southern Ground Nashville:
questions.answer: Studio Director

questions.question: Originally from:
questions.answer: Visalia, California

questions.question: How you got to Nashville:
questions.answer: I came to Nashville to join a band. The band didn't work out, but it led to many other fantastic opportunities that made me decide to stay.

questions.question: How you got to SGN:
questions.answer: I was working for Zac's record label, making records in my basement studio. The time came for the operation to grow, and I helped Zac find the facility and open the studio.

questions.question: Favorite Studio Mama Creation:
questions.answer: Levi Chicken followed by pound cake. Actually, forget the chicken - I'll just have the pound cake.

questions.question: Like most about SGN:
questions.answer: The studio is a home away from home. Every single bit of this place was made with love, especially the love for music, art, and the preservation of their history.

questions.question: Best part of your job:
questions.answer: Working with my co-workers. Not only are they immensely talented in their craft, they are fiercely committed to doing whatever it takes to get the job done.

questions.question: Fave piece of gear/equipment:
questions.answer: Ampex ATR-102.

questions.question: Hidden Talents?
questions.answer: I can juggle.

questions.question: Hobbies?
questions.answer: Gardening and mindlessly reading Wikipedia entries.

questions.question: Best Dollar store purchase?
questions.answer: Official Darth Vader Key Chain.

questions.question: Position at Southern Ground Nashville:
questions.answer: Studio Director/Chief Engineer

questions.question: Originally from:
questions.answer: Heber Springs, Arkansas

questions.question: How you got to Nashville:
questions.answer: In 2001 I moved to Middle TN to go to school (and chase a girl.) I graduated MTSU, married that girl and landed a great gig.

questions.question: How you got to SGN:
questions.answer: Hard work, Matt Mangano and magic.

questions.question: Favorite Studio Mama Creation:
questions.answer: Chocolate Chip Banana Bread!

questions.question: Like most about SGN:
questions.answer: Tight knit group of folks and an amazing space!

questions.question: Best part of your job:
questions.answer: The variety of tasks.  Engineering/Producing, building and fixing things, and Shakin and Howdyin!

questions.question: Fave piece of gear/equipment:
questions.answer: I really dig our API console.

questions.question: Hidden Talents?
questions.answer: I'm a pretty mean finger knitter.

questions.question: Hobbies?
questions.answer: Woodworking and running.

questions.question: Best Dollar store purchase?
questions.answer: How can you compete with a $1 whoopie cushion?

questions.question: Position at Southern Ground Nashville:
questions.answer: Studio Mama

questions.question: Originally from:
questions.answer: Columbus, Georgia

questions.question: How you got to Nashville:
questions.answer: In April of 2012, my family visited Nashville over Spring Break, while The Wood Brothers (my husband’s band) were working on a project.  We visited the studio at that time since the band was on the Southern Ground label at the time.  We all fell in love with the city.  Oliver and I went back to Atlanta after spending a week here and decided to consider moving.  We moved into a rental house sight-unseen that very July.

questions.question: How you got to SGN:
questions.answer: After the adventure of moving fairly suddenly, getting the kids registered for school, and unpacking our lives, I set to the adventure of finding work. I sent my resume to nearly every contact I had and did some cold-calling. One afternoon, I decided to send my resume to Zac, knowing that he’d have plenty of contacts in Nashville. He then forwarded it to Matt Mangano, the studio’s Director, since the studio was just getting ready for regular use. Matt hired me, neither of us knowing exactly what the job was going to be.  I’ve loved every day here since!!

questions.question: Favorite Studio Mama Creation:
questions.answer: Levi Lowry Chicken (chicken leg quarters marinated in a mix of soy sauce, orange marmalade, fresh ginger, and mustard powder) with brown rice and stir fry vegetables.  Poundcake or Blackberry Cobbler.

questions.question: Like most about SGN:
questions.answer: The smell of wood and baked goods.

questions.question: Best part of your job:
questions.answer: This job allows me to wear all my best hats. I equally enjoy the personal and professional relationships I build and the days I get to spend at my desk doing expense reports and booking.

questions.question: Fave piece of gear/equipment:
questions.answer: CAST IRON SKILLETS!

questions.question: Hidden Talents?
questions.answer: Building crafty puppets, lanterns, and putting together crazy costumes for my Krewe of the Grateful Gluttons events in Atlanta.

questions.question: Hobbies?
questions.answer: Cooking, baking, crafting, good whiskey.

questions.question: Best Dollar store purchase?
questions.answer: Glowsticks, duh.

questions.question: Originally from:
questions.answer: My family is from Tuscaloosa, AL, but I grew up in Brookhaven, MS.

questions.question: How you got to Nashville:
questions.answer: After a run in L.A. I converted a school bus into a tiny home, and moved here for school.

questions.question: How you got to SGN:
questions.answer: Upon graduating from the Blackbird Academy, I landed an internship that fortunately blossomed into what was supposed to be a part time opportunity. I've been coming back every day since, and wouldn't have it any other way.

questions.question: Favorite Studio Mama Creation:
questions.answer: The succotash lights up my heart just by thinking about it; however, the my favorite creation of hers is the incredible energy that she works so hard to fill this place with.

questions.question: Like Most About SGN:
questions.answer: The people... The vibe... Southern Ground feels like home, it feels like work, it feels like the magic store.  It's something different every day, but it's always something special.

questions.question: Best part of your job:
questions.answer: Having the opportunity to watch some of the greatest players and minds in music get together and create, almost daily, is something I could never express enough gratitude for.

questions.question: Favorite piece of Gear/equipment:
questions.answer: The API Legacy plus in Studio A holds a special place in my heart.

questions.question: Hidden Talents:
questions.answer: I do accents fairly well.

questions.question: Hobbies:
questions.answer: Yoga has become one of my favorite downtime activities.

questions.question: Best dollar store purchase:
questions.answer: The candy is always the winner at the dollar store.  Name brand candy for 1$ instead of the 4$ at the theater? I think so.

questions.question: Originally from:
questions.answer: I grew up in Geneva, New York.  It’s a small town in a region of western NY called The Finger Lakes, east of Buffalo and just south of Lake Ontario.

questions.question: How you got to Nashville:
questions.answer: I came to Nashville to attend The Blackbird Academy.  I’d been involved in music production and recording for years but I knew there was still so much to learn, and Blackbird seemed like a great place to start.  Before moving here, I was working as a recording engineer/music tech specialist for a university in Virginia.  It was a good job, but it offered little room for growth or upward mobility.  During my fourth year, I was told that a large pay cut was in my future if I continued to work there.  I decided enough was enough and set off for Nashville.

questions.question: How you got to SGN:
questions.answer: My Blackbird class visited SGN for a tour during the end of our term.  I was so captivated by the space that I couldn’t help but ask, “who do I need to kill in order to work here?”  They subtly pointed out one of their newer interns, surely you can figure out what happened next…

questions.question: Favorite Studio Mama creation:
questions.answer: Her mashed sweet potatoes.  No question.  There’s some powerful magic at work there.

questions.question: Like most about SGN:
questions.answer: Without a doubt, my coworkers and the attitude we collectively foster in the studio.  SGN is a place where incredible work is done in a manner that is professional, yet relaxed, and demanding, yet fun.  This would not be possible without the exceptional human beings that keep the gears turning.  Everyone is a team player, no task is too small, and we all genuinely care about each other.  I cannot begin to articulate how much of a difference this makes.

questions.question: Best part of your job:
questions.answer: I get to work in a world class studio, one that is as unique as it is impressive.  The building itself has just as much character as the people in it.  I am constantly learning new things and meeting new people in this incredible space.

questions.question: Favorite Piece of gear/equipment:
questions.answer: Our pair of custom Atomic Murderphonic mains in the Studio A control room.  I mean, come on.

questions.question: Hidden Talents:
questions.answer: I’ll let you know when I find them.

questions.question: Hobbies:
questions.answer: Photography, electronic music composition/sound design, hiking, biking, learning about military history, learning to play piano, drone stuff, watching Youtube videos about huge boats.

questions.question: Best dollar store purchase:
questions.answer: It is hard to describe how many balloons you can buy at the dollar store for so very, very little.

questions.question: Originally From:
questions.answer: Decatur, AL.

questions.question: How you got to Nashville:
questions.answer: I moved out to Bozeman, Montana from Alabama and went to college for chemical engineering. While I was there I joined a band and play all over the west and midwest. I started recording our music in my house because there weren’t many places to record in Bozeman. I  then built a studio and started recording local groups when I realized this was what I really wanted to do full time. I decided to move to Nashville because it would put me close to home and the music city.

questions.question: How you got to SGN:
questions.answer: I meet Brandon a few times at audio events around town. I had heard that they maybe looking for someone that could do tech work and audio engineering too. I was working doing freelance tech work and recording so I thought this was a perfect fit so I gave him a ring. Glad I did!!

questions.question: Favorite Studio Mama Creation:
questions.answer: Wow that’s a hard one! I have a sweet-tooth so the lemon bars are amazing and of course Cornbread!

questions.question: Like Most About SGN:
questions.answer: The people I work with, like a family from day one.

questions.question: Best part of your job:
questions.answer: Taking stuff a part and putting it back together. Also getting to hear music as it’s being created.

questions.question: Favorite piece of Gear/equipment:
questions.answer: API is really great but I love studio A’s Live Room.

questions.question: Hidden Talents:
questions.answer: If I reveal them they wouldn’t be hidden anymore.

questions.question: Hobbies:
questions.answer: Riding my motorcycle, road trips, songwriting, playing frisbee with my dog Bosco Stubbs

questions.question: Best dollar store purchase:
questions.answer: Water Balloons

list.name: Kris Kristofferson
list.title: The Silver Tongued Devil and I

equipment: MANY OTHER UNUSUAL MICROPHONES AVAILABLE BY REQUEST
